perturbation.original_text:
1.5 Right of Recovery. The Investment Adviser shall have the option to recover the full amount waived, paid or reimbursed (the Expense
Waiver) by the Investment Adviser on any day on which the Fund's Net Investment Income exceeds zero. In no event, however, shall
the Expense Waiver, or any portion thereof, constitute an obligation of the Fund to the Investment Adviser on any such day unless
the Investment Adviser has expressly exercised its right to recover all or a portion of the Expense Waiver on that day, in which case
such portion of the Expense Waiver elected by the Investment Adviser for recovery that day shall then be due and payable. If, and to
the extent, the payment by the Fund to the Investment Adviser of the Expense Waiver would cause the Fund's Net Investment Income
to fall below zero, such payment shall be deferred until such date on which the
perturbation.changed_text:
4.4. Right of Recovery. The Investment Adviser shall have the option to potentially recover some amount waived, paid or reimbursed (the Expense
Waiver) by the Investment Adviser on any day on which the Fund's Net Investment Income may exceed zero. In any event, however, the Expense Waiver, or any portion thereof, will constitute an obligation of the Fund to the Investment Adviser on any such day if the Investment Adviser somehow exercised its right to recover all or a portion of the Expense Waiver on that day, in which case such portion of the Expense Waiver elected by the Investment Adviser for recovery that day is not then necessarily due and payable. If, and to the extent, the payment by the Fund to the Investment Adviser of the Expense Waiver would not cause the Fund's Net Investment Income to fall below zero, such payment will not be deferred until such date on which the
perturbation.explanation: The original 'Right of Recovery' clause clearly outlines the Investment Adviser's ability to recover waived expenses. The modification introduces ambiguity by using words like 'potentially,' 'may,' 'somehow,' and 'not necessarily,' undermining the clarity and enforceability of the right to recovery. The clause also now appears under the Miscellaneous section, further obscuring its importance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940 - clarity and transparency requirements for fund operations.

perturbation.original_text:
This Agreement shall continue in effect for a period of one year from the date of its execution and from year to year thereafter provided such
continuance is specifically approved by a majority of the trustees of the Trust who (i) are not "interested persons" of the Trust or any other party
to this Agreement, as defined in the 1940 Act, and (ii) have no direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of this Agreement ("Non-
Interested Trustees"). This Agreement will terminate upon the termination of the Advisory Agreement except the Investment Adviser's Right of
Recovery set forth in section 1.5 herein.
perturbation.changed_text:
This Agreement shall continue in effect maybe for a period of one year from the date of its execution and from year to year thereafter provided such
continuance is vaguely approved by a majority of some trustees of the Trust who (i) are "interested persons" of the Trust or any other party
to this Agreement, as poorly defined in the 1940 Act, and (ii) may have a direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of this Agreement ("Potentially Interested Trustees"). This Agreement will terminate upon maybe the termination of the Advisory Agreement except the Investment Adviser's Right of
Potential Recovery possibly set forth in section 4.4 herein.
perturbation.explanation: By introducing uncertainty ('maybe,' 'vaguely,' 'some,' 'potentially') and mischaracterizing key terms ('interested persons' become 'potentially interested trustees', the agreement is weakened. The original clause provided a clear renewal process; the modification creates doubt about the validity and continuation of the agreement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940 - independence requirements for fund trustees and clarity in contractual agreements.

perturbation.original_text:
If the Investment Adviser is required to reimburse the Fund, the Investment Adviser shall make such payment within 30 days
after each month-end in the amount due the Fund as of each month. If the Fund is required to pay the Investment Adviser the Expense
Waiver, the Fund shall make such payment within 30 days after each month-end. Reimbursements to the Fund or the Expense Waiver
shall not include any additional charges or fees whatsoever, including, e.g., interest accruable on such reimbursements or the Expense
Waiver.
perturbation.changed_text:
If the Investment Adviser is maybe required to reimburse the Fund, the Investment Adviser might make such payment approximately within 30 days
after potentially each month-end in roughly the amount due the Fund as of each month. If the Fund is potentially required to pay the Investment Adviser the Expense
Waiver, the Fund shall probably make such payment within maybe 30 days after potentially each month-end. Reimbursements to the Fund or the Expense Waiver
may include additional charges or fees potentially, including, e.g., interest accruable on such reimbursements or the Expense
Waiver.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause provided a clear timeline for reimbursements. The modification introduces ambiguity about how the Investment Adviser would be reimbursed by creating flexible payment periods, thereby violating the contract's clarity.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Investment Company Act of 1940 - accurate disclosure of financial arrangements.
